description: From Middle English menden, by apheresis for amenden (“to amend”); see amend.

entries.meaning: A place, as in clothing, which has been repaired by mending.
The act of repairing or recovering.
examples: My trousers have a big rip in them and need a mend.

verbs.description: mend (third-person singular simple present mends, present participle mending, simple past and past participle mended)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To repair (something that is torn, broken, defaced, decayed, or otherwise damaged)
examples: My trousers have a big rip in them and need mending.
When your car breaks down, you can take it to the garage to have it mended.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put in a better state; to set right; to reform;
examples: Her stutter was mended by a speech therapist.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To help, to advance, to further; to add to.
examples: Though in some lands the grass is but short, yet it  […] mends garden herbs and fruit.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To grow better; to advance to a better state; to become improved.
examples: We have had terrible rains these two or three days. I intended to dine at lord treasurer's, but went to see lady Abercorn, who is come to town, and my lord; and I dined with them, and visited lord treasurer this evening. His porter is mending.
